Example :  A family member goes on vacation, so on July 27th, they have dinner out in a restaurant.  They spend approximately $90.00.  While the family is traveling, a family member does not eat food other than what the restaurant provides.  On Aug. 2, they stop in a second restaurant.  They spend $120.00.  While in the second restaurant, they do not eat food that was brought to them.  For example, they do not eat the $16.00 burger.  Because they already had dinner, they just pay the bill instead of getting another $16.00 burger for dinner.  On Aug. 3, once back in their home country, they spend a total of $45.00.  If they do not eat anything else and simply buy bottled water, their total bill is $60.00. If they buy groceries at the supermarket in their country, they spend less than $40.00.  If their country does not have an ATM in the place where they are staying, their total bill would be $55.00.<n>Input: How much would each person be charged by the IRS if they fail to file a tax return?<n>Output: $1,400.00<n><n>Input:How will changing the way that money is earned affect the economy as a whole? A: Money earned at the grocery store, such as from the sale of groceries, is considered consumer goods, which mean it is subject to value-added taxes. Therefore changing the way that money at a grocery store is earned can reduce the amount of money that the grocery store can spend on other consumer goods.<n>B: People have a hard time saving money when they spend

One of the two men asks, "Where do we turn around?"<n>Output: A<n><n>Enterprise resource planning software and database technology offers employees unprecedented flexibility for personal and business life. The software can help managers keep employees on course and stay ahead of changes in the marketplace. However, it can also pose problems. These include conflicts of interest, confusion about who to contact or how to use the computer system, and a lack of knowledge about how to make most of its capabilities really work. By using some of today's essential enterprise resource planning (ERP) software and database technology, however, businesses can make an immediate and lasting impact on how their organization performs.<n>This two-day symposium, which will be held Friday and Saturday at the University of Utah Business School, brings together key business and ERP experts, leading ERP vendors, program managers, and system analysts. Topics will range from what ERP software is and how to choose one to the use of database technologies, such as Oracle Java ERP. More than 100 corporate managers, procurement, accounting, human resources, and other executives in manufacturing, energy and transportation, retail, education, and health care will explore the best strategies and solutions for managing and running their organizations.<n>This is the third year the conference has been held. For more information, call Utah Business School Business School at 435-652-7200 or visit www

Each student usually attends one session where the group organizes an event at the University.  If four students attend and two come and go, the number of students attending is in the half of the student population.<n>Output: D-2<n>Another ten-person group might cause a problem for two teams of twelve people each.  Each team has twelve people and everyone goes to the first party.  The total numbers attending are the student population of the University.  The number is divided by the number of teams.  This means that the total number attending is smaller.  Then the game that the teams play is based on the smaller number.  The number of rounds that it lasts is also based on the smaller numbers.  The total games played is also based on the larger numbers.<n>Output: D<n>The last group of students attends a social group at the University.  The student population will usually be in the majority of the students attending.  The group organizes various social events each week that the group organizes.  It is not as

There are only a hundred different possible things that could happen to the bat when it hits a ball (such as a hard ball, a fly ball, a home run, a game-winning home run, a bad catch, or a strikeout).  For every 1,000 different things that could happen to a bat when it hits a balls, there are 300,000 equally likely and equally unlikely things that could happen to me.  If I hit the ball with the bat and it goes flying through the air, the bat will have 3/4 of the force of a regular bat but it will still give an equal number of force to the ball that it hits.  For every 1,001 different other things that could happen to either of my objects, there are 300,001 equally possible and equally unlikely objects that could happen to me or mine. Suppose I hit the ball with a bat and it stays aloft. Then how many different objects could possibly happen that cause me or mine to fall?  We will count them one at a time. In doing so, I can calculate the percentage of the things that could possibly happen to me but that could possibly cause me to fall that are zero.  If there is no zero, then how many objects can possibly cause me to fall?<n>Output: 0<n><n>Input: You buy 50 chocolate bars, each weighing about 60 grams. One of the rooms in the house (not your bedroom) has the highest rent in the area. It costs $400 a month to have the room rented out for the same amount. How much is your annual income?<n>Output: $150K<n><n>Input: The average person on average consumes 100,000 calories a day. To get that much you have to take the equivalent of a 10,000 calorie a day diet, 3 days a week, with exercise on the other days. Assuming that you consume about a half dozen meals a day (some of which won’t have energy), eating that many calories per day eats up your lunch allowance. To get that much from the same food it’d take 4-5 hours of cooking one meal on those days. But those are not working days, and those meals are better for you (especially if you exercise). Assuming that you exercise on those days as well, you should be able to consume a lot more calories than 100kcal a day, if you work just 2 hours at the gym. So, to get that much you’d need to lift weights and do exercise. Assuming that your diet is well-balanced, and exercises are done for at least 20 minutes every two hours, and that you follow the guidelines for a balanced diet it should be possible to eat around 80kcal. Note that if you’re very active, only lifting weights or doing any kind of activity for longer than 5 minutes each hour you’ll burn less calories, and if you’re sedentary you’ll burn more calories in those situations. So, in a nutshell, if you eat very well and exercise at least 5-6 hours per day the total calories you’ll consume will not exceed 60kcal/day. Using the numbers above, if you eat 100kcal a day in calories, and exercise for 2 hours 3 days per week you’ll consume 1,200kcal over your lifetime – so that works out to be about 4-5 times the recommended daily calorie intake. Using the previous figures of 10k a day being enough protein to meet daily requirements, the recommendation is that you should get at least a third of your daily calories from protein (that’s half your recommended daily sodium intake if you take a low-sodium diet). Assuming you get 1.4g/pound of muscle mass,

Each player answers half the questions correctly or the word will turn to a question and he has to answer half the questions correctly.  After the player answers five questions correctly or he passes the question he goes to the next, while he is on a certain turn if the player answers two questions correctly before reaching the end the word turns to an other question and the next turn the player answers half the questions. This game is played for two hours and one score is counted per question and the player must have answered five questions correctly before he can leave.  The questions in this section of the quiz are designed to be easy to answer so that there is no way for a player to cheat.

In the example given above, how would you have divided the $12- $8? In the example given above how would you have divied up the nuts and dried fruits?<n><n>2. If your answers to task #1 and #2 are the same, how many kilos would your nuts and dried fruit cost you to buy? For example, if you bought a kilo of nuts for $12 and a kilo of dried fruit cost $8, then your total cost would be: $12 - $8 = $6<n><n>3. If your answers to #2 and #3 are the same, how would you answer #2? In particular, you have 2 options:<n><n>1. Would the price of the nuts be the same as the amount you paid for them, or would the price be less than half what you paid (i.e. you would save $6 if you bought them for $6 each instead of $12)?<n>2. Would the price of dried fruit be the same as the price it cost you to buy the nuts, or would the price of dried fruit also be half as much (i.e. $8 instead of $12)? In either case, you would have saved $6.<n><n>4. In the example given here, if you bought a third kilo of nuts for the same as you paid for the first two kilos, your cost for the third kilo would be $3: $12 - $3 = $4.<n>In other words, if you bought a 3 kilo bag of nuts for ten dollars, you would spend ten dollars.<n><n>For this question, ask one or more of these alternative questions:<n><n>* How much would it cost to buy a kilo of nuts and a kilo of dry fruits for $12?<n>* How much would you pay to buy 1 kilo

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Output: 868<n><n>Input:Where is a note likely to indicate a melody? Choices:  A: fridge B: a classroom C: envelope D: medical chart E: sheet music<n>Output:		 _____ If I put a note on my fridge it would be a song, If I put one on a piece of paper it would be a melody. If I put one on my window it would be a melody, If I put one over my head it would be a song. But if I put one on my fridge it would only be a little tune. If I put one over the keypad it would just be that little ditty I sing along to as soon as I open the fridge. If I put one outside it would be something meaningful. If I put one at the bottom of the fridge it would not be meaningful. If I have to change one I can't put it on the fridge. The note might be on the bottom, but the melody doesn't seem too deep. So, the most likely place where I can put the note would be on a classroom floor. The melody could be in the left hand corner, but I don't think it's deep enough because it's just a single note. The melody could probably be on the sheet music right next to the door, so long as I put down the right-hand sheet music. But the left-hand sheet music should be put somewhere with an arrow pointing left, so I can't put the melody on it. I think I can place it in the middle, but I have to rearrange the sheet music. I can put it on a floor, but I think I have to remove the right-hand corner first. The melody might be on the whiteboard next to the right-hand corner, but I don' t think the melody is deep enough. I might put it on a whiteboard under the chalkboard, but I think the melody isn't deep enough. So I can't place it under the chalkboard. And if I put it under the chalkboard I can't put the note on the fridge, and the melody won't sound good and would probably sound boring. So I might put it on the fridge, but it would have to be below the fridge and I can't put it there. It won't sound good and wouldn't be meaningful at all. I might put it in front of a picture, but the melody would be underneath it. It won't sound like a melody and would make the picture even more boring. But, I think I can't put the fridge melody under the picture because of the chalkboard. I wonder what you think. I've added a note so I can listen to it while I type.<n>

That $12 would be worth $40 today in the price of oil. The oil was used about 4 times during the day. If the pie was baked, removed from the pan and eaten at market B, it would have cost you $5.10 and still have the same amount of calories. If used at market A, the pie would cost $7 and the amount of calories would be increased to 987. But the pies were made by market B, not market B. Output: 15<n><n>Input:If you’re a student at John Hopkins University, you are in a group of four. Choices:a: 4 miles b: 12 miles c: 13.4 miles d: 12.6 miles e: 7.8 miles f: 7.4 miles g: 6 miles h: 6.2 miles<n> Output: 5<n><n>In order to compare two things in time, you must make sure that you’re using time units that are the same size as them. You shouldn’t compare two objects that are different from each other. You can, however, compare two things that are exactly the same, the way we are to compare the days you spend with the days other people spend with them.<n><n>For example, if you have two coins (a quarter and a dime) that are exactly the same in weight. You can calculate, using the decimal system that we have now, exactly how long they take to get to the end of a block of sand. (We already know that they take 24 seconds to move 1 block, so using the half-block rule and subtracting 24 seconds from the length of a coin, we get 0.3 meters. A half-block

The word 'orchestra' should be 'orchestre'."<n><n>The word "orchestre", instead of "orchestra" should be "orchestra". "Orchestre" means ensemble, while "orchestra" means orchestra.<n><n>For the second question I don't understand the answer "and the total number of goals" but I can accept the answer of "10".<n><n>The answer for the first question is correct. If the average value over the whole league is 100 goals per side, the number of goals scored for Barcelona in the League of Nations should be 300, and the number of goals scored against them should be 200. I think they could have worded it differently.

If you have additional questions or comments, I'd like to hear from you as well, so please post a question or comment about this topic on the board or by email.<n><n>* NOTE: The class above was adapted from the Stanford Mathematics Problem Solvers Online Classwork for the Fall 2009 Semester.  It's an interactive class for anyone who really likes solving math problems online, so be sure to sign up for regular opportunities to come up with your own problem!  The class is also open to everyone who is interested to learn from these problems, be it during your commute on a quiet bus or sitting in your own office from home.  If you think that this sort of thing would be fun with your own coworkers, you should check out the class's web page as well.  We hope that you'll find it informative and rewarding as well!

How many hours of work each week are they assigned and how much have they done?<n>Output: 60<n><n>Output:Two people are travelling. One person is left driving alone from point A to point B whilst the other drives from point B to A. At each point they have to restock every fuel and restock the restock fuel and the restock the restock  fuel. How many restock fuel do they fill in a week?<n>Output [10,000: 10,000 × 1000]: 10,000<n><n>Input:Suppose an automobile breaks down after traveling 600 miles. The break down consumes approximately 80 gallons of fuel a day. Each day, John and Tom will fill 80 gallons of fuel per car. If the break down was on a highway with no exits, how many miles would they have to travel to reach a service station?<n>Output: 10,000 / 800 = 1,000<n><n>Input [10,000: 9,000 × 1000]: 8,000<n><n>Input.[10,000: 8,000 × 8000]: 6,000<n><n>Input.The average speed of a train in a certain region is 40 miles a hour. How many miles per hour does the train travel in that region?<n>Output. 5, 000 × 1000<n><n>Input:A bus and a taxi will go down a road at the same time. A bus driver takes 10 minutes to arrive in destination and a taxi takes 2 minutes. The taxi driver drives on the left side and the bus driver takes a right turn. The time between the first two cars makes 40 minutes. The time between the third car and the fourth car makes 40 minutes. The second car drives for 40 minutes. The third car drives for 40 minutes, and the 4th car drives for 20 minutes. How many minutes does each car drive for?<n>Output: 100<n><n>Input:The following numbers are printed on the sideboard in a restaurant. They do not correspond to each other on the board and do not mean anything. They correspond to 1,400, 200, 4, and 3. How many plates are there in the restaurant?<n>Output: 100 + 100, 400, 200, 4

We also will now be using a more computerized computer because we find it easier to explain a lot of the problems with handwritten equations.  I have also added some very easy to understand tables to guide students in their analysis, particularly for times when it is unclear what to assume. The most frequent items by weight groups include: food and drinks, beverages and non-food items, personal items, clothing and footwear, paper and other products, household items, household appliances, electrical products, household cleaning and dry cleaning supplies, office supplies, office supplies, computer products, paper and paper products, and miscellaneous goods. The most frequent items per category include: household items, groceries, food, household wares, and miscellaneous goods (eg CDs and movies). The items that the most frequently appear within one weight group are likely to be bought within the same weight group too. The most frequently appearing items across all weight groups are likely to be bought among all weights. This list of common items is known as the “usual consumer list”.<n>Output: 36<n><n>Input: How many people go in and out of your country?  You can count the number of people who go in and out of different countries, for example: China to Canada, and Canada to China, how many times. Then use the average of the amount of people who travel between each place in each year.  Then use a number less than 200, that is: 20,000,000. Then using a number up to 200, that is: 500,000,000, or 1 million,000.  Finally, divide by 2, which is: 100,000,000. This survey is designed to gauge what people need & want, so if you are interested in participating in this survey, please click on the link below to register:<n><n>Your input is essential to helping your elected officials and transportation advocates understand how to address transportation needs in the nation.  Please use the link above if you're interested in helping.

Choices:  A: roof B: room C: floor D: apartment E: neighbor's house<n>Output:		 house<n><n>Input:The average number of calories required by a typical human each day for survival is 3,400, and we burn 5,100–7,500 calories each day in our daily activities. An average adult consumes 600 calories while standing, walking, exercising, or doing other activities. In the past, it was thought that these averages meant the total calories consumed a week by an average human was about 5500, or about 15,500 calories. However researchers now believe these amounts may be low because normal people are more active than active adults. In this study, subjects were instructed to walk around a room 2–5 times a week for 30 minutes, without lifting their feet, for the first 10 weeks of the study, when they were told to take their daily calorie and activity counts on paper, and then to report how many calories and how many calories’ calories were burned. A group of researchers found that a person’s weight when measured at the beginning and the end of the study dropped by 2.33% per week. This effect was also repeated in a second study at the same time, but more than 50% of the subjects’ weights did not change. These findings indicated that people who were more active than usual were “eating less,” possibly because they were doing less physical activity.<n>Output: 6,000<n><n>Input: Every morning, Larry wakes up 45 minutes earlier than his wife, Dawn, and goes to the bathroom one hour earlier. The average man weighs 185 pounds, but weightlifting will add only 0.3 pounds per workout to his total**<n>**  4. He probably got 4 servings of water per day, and 64 ounces of fluid* - he lost 5 ounces**<n>**   5. This works out to be 3.8 ounces of fluid per week  - he lost 8 ounces<n>**  6. That's not 1,500 calories* but rather 3,600 calories - he can't go without a coffee*<n>**  7. At 12 ounces per day, 1,500 is about what he needs if he wants to lose fat (more than 25 calories per day will make his metabolism slow.  A normal-sized human body weighs 2,000 to 2,500 pounds, so that would mean that he could only eat 1,000 calories at one time.**<n>And a word on the question about the question...<n><n>I thought it would be fun to ask questions in order to encourage discussion... however, I think this particular exercise is a fairly pointless exercise - people generally ignore you without even seeing your answers (and without commenting on your answers) so my feeling was that it was essentially useless to have questions based on questions instead of answers.<n><n>In the future, I plan to ask the same type of questions about particular games and players.<n><n>(In a perfect world, we'd be able to give you the actual score of the game after you answer the questions, but all bets are off in the real world...)<n><n>The answer to #3 is A<n>The answer to #4 is<n>The answer to #5 is<n>The answer to the last question is A<n>the answer to the first question is B and D.<n>

Friedman<n>,<n>Associate Teaching Professor at<n>Northwestern University.<n><n>This article was originally published by the National Bureau of Economic Research, and is reproduced here under a Creative Commons license with attribution to Dan Fagner and Daniel H. Friedman.

How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Output: 868<n><n>Input:What is illegal to do when you play cards at a casino? John, Jack and Queen. Answer:<n><n>Output: This is a simple, and one of the most frequently asked, question from students.  Students are often not able to find out how much bodyweight they have gained, or to estimate how much weight they can gain in 12 months.  This is one of the most asked questions in college athletics, and here I am going to provide a possible solution.  I will also provide a sample answer to help students get a general handle on bodyweight.  If you are looking to add any new muscle, you should probably have a stronger diet.  You can also use the following formula to estimate the number of pounds that you can add on your current weight.<n><n>To estimate the number of ounces you will gain when you increase your bodyweight based on body type.  The first number to be added to the total bodyweight is the amount you weigh.  For example, for a person with a Body mass index of 12.5 and a height of 200 lbs, the body weight would be 24.75 pounds.  Then add an ounce to this total based on the height of 200 lbs.  This would increase your body weight by 1 ounce.  For instance: For a person with a BMI of 25, which is the average for average-sized college students, the average bodyweight would be 24.0 pounds.  Then add another 0.5 ounces to the total bodyweight based on size.  This would double your bodyweight.  Therefore, your total bodyweight would be 24-1.5=26.0 pounds.  For the remainder of this equation, which is based on body type, your bodyweight will be 24.5 pounds, your height will be 200 inches, and your age will be 20.   Since the total bodyweight is 26.0 pounds divided by 20, we get our bodyweight in ounces.  I hope this gave you a good glimpse into body weight. If you have any questions, I hope that this example answers your question.  Best of luck for your future!<n><n>

In Thanksgiving, students must choose an activity as their activity of the day and answer a multiple choice question. The goal is to get the most points possible!<n><n>I am always looking for ways that I can help students stay motivated to work in the classroom. In your students' cases, you may be concerned that they may feel they have nothing to be thankful for. So, what can you do? Here are some suggestions I have seen over the years that are effective in helping students be thankful and focused each day:<n><n>1. Place an offering of some sort for their morning's devotions<n><n>2. Read a story or scripture out of the Bible<n><n>3. Pray for help for your students<n><n>4. Tell them what a good teacher you are<n><n>5. Have them write down 10 things they are thankful for each day.<n><n>6. Thankful in the Bedroom. It's a great way to end your day as a family!<n><n>7. Read a story or passage from the Bible as a family before you go to bed.<n><n>8. In the Morning before Breakfast. Have students write the following list of things they are thankful for.<n><n>This exercise is not intended to be a strict answer to the questions above. Congratulations!You can now go ahead and submit your activity, or create another question. Remember, you are only allowed to submit one activity per week during the school year.<n><n>- You are now ready to go to the next level! You must write a question. Be sure to read about each of the steps to writing a question here:<n><n>STEP 1: Identify your topic: Find a question that the teacher assigned you and you can have fun exploring.<n><n>STEP 2: Plan your question...and then answer it! Think about what is it that you want to learn while answering this question. Try to come up with a good, easy-to-answer question. Some good ideas: What is your main goal for your question (example, How do I plan to solve an equation, How do I organize and organize an assignment, or How do I make the best impression on my next employer)? What do I want to learn from answering the question? Who do I want to ask my question to? Once you have answered the question, try to think of ways to bring out the important parts of the question. For example, asking about an employee's day should not be filled with details of the person's job: Instead, the question should focus more on how he or she accomplishes important tasks at work. A person's major responsibilities should be discussed. An accountant's job should not be covered--he should provide explanations to how he/she allocates money. In all likelihood, your answer to this question will include at least this many sentences: The accountant... How? What? Why? Why? The accountant... My... Job... My... Life...<n><n>STEP 3: Organize Your Argument: The topic should be the focus of your questions. As a writer of essays, papers, and research essays, one of my favorite tasks when writing a question is organizing it. The order in which you plan to present your answer is very important, but you need to keep in mind some other rules: Your question shouldn't include anything that your teacher covered in class (such as vocabulary words or basic information). In fact, you should try to avoid repeating the answer of last week. Instead, your answer should include some new information, as well as what you think is important. In addition, what you learn from answering the question should influence the way you prepare your answer for the next week's question. For example,

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Output: 868<n><n>Input:He called bull when his friend said a bull can be what? Choices:  A: feeble B: bullbleep C: cow D: female E: charging prey<n>Output:		 D<n><n>input:"To" is a special case of the expression, "To", that can only be used with one or more variables. The expression "(to) to" will be evaluated against the other possible variables for that expression.<n>Output:"To" does not have a default meaning.<n><n>input:"(to) To" is a special case "To" that is evaluated against the other possible values for the expression "(to) to". "To" values are also known as prefixes, and there are many kinds of prefixes.<n>Output:"To", "To", or "to" (also known as the "(to) function") can be used with any (to) variable; for example, it can be used with a variable of type int, long, double or any other type. It is also possible to use this "(to) function" with a double as a constructor parameter. However, there is no restriction as to how many times it can be used to evaluate a keyword, nor as to how many times its value can be used in the expression "(to) To". The same situation also holds for its value; in particular, in the expression "(to)" it is allowed to be used as many times as may be necessary while satisfying the statement condition for the expression "(to)" (the value is evaluated against the value of the keyword). In addition, the value "to" can be treated as any other pointer, even as long as it is assigned to a double.<n>Concretely, a value of the type "to" may be treated as a pointer to either the next item (a string), a string with a non-negative index (a numeric), or as if it were an array containing a pointer to an array (of double value only).<n>An important property of a value of the type "(to)" is that it can be evaluated as many times as may not otherwise be possible without making the result of an evaluation into a double. If the first condition is satisfied for the expression "(to)", an expression of type "(to)" can be evaluated as many as may be necessary. The expression "(to)" can be regarded as a special kind of "construction" (or "evaluation") of "const types", and thus it may be used with both "const" values in the expression "(to)", and with "const" values in other expressions. "To" also has a number of "special" properties; "To" has two distinct types of functions

If you make up a story, you are not cheating.<n>Good luck!<n><n>I found out that in my school they have a game called "I hate math" and it's a really bad one. It requires thinking, but it's pretty easy if you think about it.<n>I have a question though. Why did they make it a game about math instead of just making it something you have to do?<n><n>It's supposed to be a way of teaching math through the act of problem solving. If you could do basic calculus and trigonometry alone using your own resources you would have no reason to learn more math. This game is basically teaching you how to apply what you already know, as opposed to teaching you how to memorize facts (which can be learned through repetition and logic). I haven't studied as much physics as I want to this semester, yet my teacher is trying to make it out to be more complicated than necessary.<n><n>Because you're doing "basic calculus" and trigonometry, the fact that you need to do other stuff to get better at them is supposed to be a big help. In fact, that's how you might think of it. But, since this is a game of chance and math is the focus of chance-based games, it is possible that you are playing "less math" in this game than you are in other games.<n><n>The questions are all fairly easy to answer, but I will add one more: What if the two people scored exactly the same? Then, how do I know who was more likely to complete the game?<n><n>Because the same number counts as the same value twice, so each number is just one value that's worth more than the one before it, until you reach a finite limit.<n>The game tells you that, so you know:<n><n>That's the only way to know that you get more points for completing the game than the other person did, unless you find a way to cheat the game, I guess.<n>But, as a general rule of thumb, I would rather give a person 20 points for answering the questions correctly than giving them 0 points for guessing wrong. That's how the game gives you points: you need to guess the number correctly, or else it will show you that you have to guess "correctly" next.<n><n>Here's another problem with the game:<n>You are told to guess 7 points for each number you're

This is the only vertex in G_1 that is completely connected (the root node). Therefore, problem G_1 is a non-trivial graph! If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Output: 868<n><n>Input:What might a satisfied person do? Choices:  A: board ship B: grocery shop C: cross street D: feel happy E: shout at<n>Output:		 8<n><n>Input: How many people would be willing to pay a $20 tip at Olive Garden?<n>Output: 3<n><n>### Answer:<n>A) 3<n>B) 3<n>C) 3<n>D) 3<n>E) 3<n>F) 9<n>G) 23<n>H) 1<n><n>**Example:<n>Let's say Bob is at a party with his buddies who drink vodka and smoke crack. There are 4 people at the party: Bob's friend, Bob's buddy, Bob's buddy and Bob's buddy's wife.<n>During the festivities, there is a $20 tip on the table. Bob's buddy is going to pay $20 of that tip, so he can spend it on crack. The other 3 people will split the rest of the tip on food or drink. Bob's buddy is also giving $20 to the bartender to buy a pizza. At the door, Bob's buddy gives the bartender $2 in tips and a large drink. The bartender's tip goes to his car loan company.<n>Once the party is over, Bob's friend returns home, gets his car back and drives off into the night.<n>Bob's friend drives home to his wife and kids and immediately tells them that he's going to buy more crack.<n>Finally, the party gets over, the alcohol clears, all the drinks are gone, and the bartender leaves the bar.<n>While waiting for his wife, Bob's wife goes to the store and buys a $16 can of Pepsi. He pays that can with his check. Then he goes back home to spend his $16 of Pepsi. He drives back to Olive Garden and makes out with his wife for $70. His buddy comes out of the bar with $20 in tips, so he gives the bartender 40 cents. At the door, his buddy gives Bob's wife $80. Total tips add up to $80.<n>It might be tempting to pay Bob's buddy $20 more than the customer, and that's fine. But if you do it to Bob, you'd probably be surprised what his reaction will be. You get a "wow, thanks" for 20% of the tip. That might be enough to convince him to leave a note on your car telling you to stay away from his wife, but it's not enough to get all his friends in on the deal. They might not get that much more than Bob, unless you give them several tips that are higher than $20.<n>Remember, if you can convince Bob's wife

How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Output: 868<n><n>Input:The boy was too nervous to dance, so what was he doing progressively at the ball? Choices:  A: dance like crazy B: standing still C: wallflower D: stand still E: like dancing<n>Output:		 1<n><n>Input:If the player who scored the goal has the ball, the other player gets it.  If the other player has the ball, the player who scored the game winning goal gets it.  If both players have the ball, it’s who has the ball at time of score.  In this situation, it’s not possible for the opposing team to score any more goals.  What is the probability of a game win that way? For example, if the opposing team scores 5 goals and the team that scores the game winner scores 13, how likely is it that that team will score 10 more goals?<n>Output: 1.75<n><n>Input:If you had a football with the following dimensions, what could you do with it?<n>Output:  (2 x2=64)x(2/n)=64<n><n>Input: The player that scores the game winning goal can move it.  If someone else has the ball and scores a goal, but isn’t the scorer of the goal, he can take the ball from them.  If the ball is a pass, and the last player who scored a goal has it and passes the ball, the teammate who scores the goal can kick it to the opposing player or take it from him and score.<n>Output: 1/2<n><n>Output: If the player who scores the game winning goal gets the ball, he can kick it in the air and shoot it.  Once it leaves the field, it doesn’t return.  It’s the same if the player who scores the goals has the ball, because it’s not a fair game (no one else scores).  If the player who scores goals gets the ball, he is only as good as his shots.  The best players in the world have average-to-bad shots.  If the player that scores a field goal gets the ball, the opposing team can’t score more goals.  The worst is average-to-not-so-good shots.  What’s the probability of the team that scores an equal number of goals but that one player scores 2?  For example, if both teams score 30, is there a 50% probability of one team scoring 45?  For example, since both teams have 30 points, is there a 50/50 chance the opposing team scores 30?  For example, can you multiply two numbers 1.5 times or three times?<n>Output: 1

What is the length of a string of pearls (3 pearls)?  (3 pearls)<n>2^2.4. What is the diameter of the string of pearls (2 pearls)? (3 pearls)2^2.3. Write down the answers.<n>2^2.2. When you stretch a string of pearls, you make a loop, but the length is the same length of the string, right? (2 pearls, 1 loop) 2^2.1. What is the length from the end of the string to the end of the loop?<n>2^2.0. In other words, how many pearls can be in a loop?<n><n>(The answer to the 2nd Exercise)<n>This is the distance that an object travels (in a straight line) when traveling in a plane: x, y = 1 = 1 x2 = 64,000 x2 = 144,000

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Output: 868<n><n>Input:Where could you find an armchair that is used by only a few people? Choices:  A: doctor's office B: hospital C: apartment D: study E: furniture store<n>Output:		 80<n><n>Loading...Please wait...<n><n>Solution Preview<n><n>1.1 - Each person bought only two kilogram of nuts and two kilogram of dried fruit. You can make the money equivalent by weight.<n><n>There are two different choices.<n>1. If Adam bought 3 kilograms of almonds and two kilograms of dried fruits, he will get $12 and he will get $8<n>2. If John went to the gym 3 times per week and lifted weights for an hour, he will spend one hour each day warming up and doing cardio, and a third of his weight lifting time cooling down and doing cardio. So he'll get a total of 3 hours at the gym.<n><n>These two answers show that the problem is "to what extent can you estimate the number of hours people spend at the gym, on average"<n><n>1. This one is about how to estimate the number of hours. I think it is very important. In fact it is a really big problem. I think it is a critical problem in economics, because it deals with all the things we have to pay attention about and we have to estimate their cost.<n><n>If we know that John's total daily activity time is 3 hours, I would guess that he spend less time in the gym than Adam. But we don't know that, we just have some general idea about how much work John does per day, and compare this in different activities. This idea is called "cost of free time". I don't believe you can be completely sure that this is the case, because people have varying capacities, for physical activities (not just mental activities). Also, this idea is not very good. People spend time "unconsciously" in the gym. So I think it would not be a good assumption to make. If you want to really spend more time in the gym than you are spending right now, you simply have to do some serious physical activities like running, swimming, etc. This is like running an hour a day on a stationary bike. And this is more of a question about time as an object and physical activity. We will talk about the idea about the generalization of "free time" that some people will spend time in the gym than others, but I think that the idea of free time is not as simple as saying "John spends less time in the gym then Adam" It is something like "Adam is more relaxed than John". But this idea is not very useful because we don't know that John is "more relaxed

Where is the screwdriver? If the input is 1 it is output = 2. Input and Output are the same in other forms.<n><n>Input/Output<n>input = +Output = = = = = =<n>input =<n>output = = = = = (= = = = = =)<n><n>Input and Output: =<n>1) input = Output<n>2) input = output (variable) = Output<n><n>The Input is a variable and therefore can either be multiplied or truncated. That means that any positive value can be multiplied or truncated, i.e. any positive integer can be multiplied.<n><n>Output is a variable that has no direct relation to any other variable. The Output is an operand that is itself a variable. For example, we could say that the output of the Calculator is a variable if the output of the calculator is a variable. Similarly, the output of the Calculator cannot be the result of a single input. The Output can be calculated by subtracting 1 or by using an expression to substitute 1 for output.<n><n>Input: 5, 2 = 5<n>Output: 5, 2 = 6<n>Input: -2, -2 = -2<n>Output: -3, -3 = 3<n><n>Input: 2, 5 = 1<n>Output

The same time span would take 3 days for a man to complete his usual daily tasks at home.  John eats 3 meals a day (two at home and one at the gym) at a caloric intake of 3,000 which equates to his weight.  This implies that John consumes roughly 15,000 calories every day.  If he exercised for two hours he burns one pound of fat every hour or approximately 60 minutes at a slow pace, and burns an additional 20 lbs of fat during each training session.  For two days in a row, he consumes an additional 1640 calories for a total weight of 24,080.  Based on these calculations, he burns an average of 3500 calories daily (30,000 calories a day minus 2,000 calories burned during exercise) and eats an average weight of 2420 pounds.  Based on this information, it can be assumed that John eats roughly 2.3 pounds of food each day.  John has a body mass index of 26 and an hour of daily activity is roughly equivalent to eating roughly 2,500 calories.<n><n>Input: The two players on the field for football each run 7.5 miles per week.  At a 6% grade school pace and 1 mph per mile, this is equivalent to a 1 mile run. When asked to run a mile, the speed is typically recorded at 13-14 mph.  A person’s metabolic rate (what a person burns each day) in 3% grade of aerobic activity equals about 2000 calories.  If each running mile is valued at 10 calories per kg of body weight, that person has burned about 1700 calories.  To consume 17000 calories would require a daily calorie intake of 32,000.  That would mean that John is eating roughly 2.6 pounds of food each day, or 2550 calories each day.  Based on these values, a person consuming roughly 2.6 pounds per day would burn an average of 3500-4000 calories per day. Choices:  A: opera B: supermarket C: building D: conference E: apartment<n>Output:		 2<n><n>Click to expand...<n><n>* First, the player does the math in his head. He knows the total cost of the snacks he brought (2.5 kg nuts and 12 kg fruits for $12.00). He knows the total number of nuts and fruits that the other person bought (3kg nuts and 2.5 kg fruits for $8.00). He knows that it will cost him $8.00 to buy the nuts and fruits. He knows how many minutes the game will last and roughly how much total food he needs. Based on all these assumptions, he comes up with the answer: $8.00.<n>* He then goes to his fridge, opens the door, removes the required items as quickly as possible (2.5kg of nuts in the same 2.5kg plastic package takes about 5 seconds) and returns it as quickly as possible (3kg of nuts is $10 per kg and takes about 5 minutes).<n>* Finally, he adds up his purchases and buys a total of $5.16. He has enough cash for the food so now he can go upstairs.<n>* In his head, he has done this calculation twice using exact numbers. He has now learned to do these things using the money. In fact, now at the very top of the list is the food.<n>* He is now off to his office to collect his new snack.<n>* At work, things take a little while: he makes sure there are no wires hanging around inside of the office and unplugs everything from his computer. He then connects everything to the USB slot in the bottom of his desk and boots up his computer.<n><n>To get an idea of how much he needs to buy: we could take this step at the end of the game using the exact number or make a chart to compare (using the sum method instead of percentage):<n><n>The first calculation is the direct sum - i.e. how much the player needs to bring to the end of the game. It is the amount he needs to spend on the nuts and fruits.<n>*<n>*<n>*<n><n>The reason the direct sum isn't directly multiplied is that there are lots of subtleties and round-trips to make sure we have all the data as close to 1$ as possible. Let's assume that the player is really hungry or tired and gets 3,000 calories from the peanuts and fruits.<n>* We want to bring in another 3,000 calories because now he has

It is true also that many people choose not to drive automobiles due to environmental concerns. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Output: 868<n><n>Input:The president had to make a decision regarding the hate attack on his country, what did he do? Choices:  A: wage war B: fight enemy C: kill D: destroy enemy E: attacked his country<n>Output:		 100<n><n>Input: A football team plays a match at home against a home team, both teams score the same number of goals. If both sides score six more goals, divide the total number of goals by 20, and add the amount of goals scored by the visitors team. The visitors team did not score more goals during the entire match than the home team.  Calculate the number of goals scored.<n>Output: 100<n>(The visitors did not score more goals, divide the number of goals scored by 20.)<n>(Total number of goals - number of goals scored by visitors) divided by 20 is 100 divided by two or twenty, in which case (a) it is six and (b) it is 6 divided by 20.<n>The total number of goals is 6 divided by 20 - the number of goals scored - by each team, divided by two - the number of goals that both teams scored during the entire match (the visitors did not score more than the home team did).<n>The visitors did not score any more goals than the home team. So, the number of goals scored is 6 divided by 20, two divided by sixteen - the number of goals the visitors team scored during the entire match.<n>The home team did not score more than four goals. So, the home team scored 12 goals.<n>The total number to which the visitors team scored is 12 divided by 16, two divided by sixteen. So, the total number is twelve divided by sixteen.<n>The total number where the visitors team scored less than the home team is 12 divided by 16. So, the total is twelve divided by sixteen divided by two.<n>The total number cannot be obtained.<n><n>Input: A.B.C.D.E.<n>Output: 5.5, 5.5, 5, 5.5.<n><n>Input: In 1998, the University of Minnesota spent $70,000,000 to build a new facility in order to improve the status of the basketball team. Calculate the average value of the tickets to the game.<n>Output: 35,000<n><n>Input: In a business environment, every day, for each hour spent in the office, a CEO makes a 50¢. Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Output: 868<n><n>Input:Where would you be able to hear a bassoon played in an unpleasing fashion? Choices:  A: orchestra B: baritone woodwind sound C: symphony D: play music E: high school band<n>Output:		 14,828<n><n>Input: A man has a wife, two children, and many cats. Every day he takes his children to school and gives them lunch. His wife makes dinner and delivers it home in the evening.    What does he spend an average of $100 to $150 per week?<n>Output: $16,000<n><n>Input: Every year the university needs to raise $2.5 Million to fund programs and events.  For that purpose, students must sign up for courses that they will either fill or leave unpaid.  At the same time, they must pay the university tuition and fees.  Do you think that these courses and fees are worth $4,000?  If so, choose one and write the cost down below.<n>Output: 5<n><n>Input: The year 1994 was marked as the most expensive year for home renovations in Canadian history. The average cost of a home renovation there was between $200,000 and $400,000.  How much would you have spent in 1994 to remodel your home?  Answer: $10,000<n>Output: 60,000<n><n>Input and output answers below, both by David Haysler
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Output: 868<n><n>Input:The game was on sale.  I got it then because it was usually what? Choices:  A: buying B: purchase C: overpriced D: way to much E: expensive<n>Output:		 A<n><n>Input: James wanted to purchase three of the same vehicle.  He didn’t because they were too expensive. I asked him why and he responded by saying they were too expensive because of how many of them were missing.  Would you accept this explanation?  Or should the explanation be that he wasn’t interested enough to buy an entire vehicle?  Or both?<n>Output: A<n>A: If the price is at X% (price), and the missing piece is at Y% of the total, you would buy two.<n>B: Would you pay more because of the missing piece? If so, yes.<n>C: If you paid the same, but the price dropped to Y% of the final, value, then you should not have bought more.<n>D: You should have purchased the missing part.<n>E: You should have purchased three of the same vehicle for the same price.   If you paid $3,000 for the vehicle plus $2,500 for a missing part, then you would have been better off by purchasing the total number of parts that you wanted. $3,000 is a fair price for a complete vehicle, missing or not.<n>F: If the price is $4,000, and the missing vehicle costs $2,500 to repair, you probably won’t purchase any part.<n>G: If you paid $6,000 for the vehicle but the missing part costs $900 to repair, you probably will not purchase anything.<n>H: If the price is 5% less than what you paid $5,000, then you probably won’te buy anything.<n>I: If you paid $4,500 for the vehicle plus the missing part, you would probably purchase something. Otherwise, you should have not purchased anything.<n>J: If the price is 8% less than the total, you probably won‘te buy anything. However, the missing piece may be worth $300 to $200 more than the total.  You may have enough money left to replace the missing part.<n>K: If the price is 10% less than the total for a complete vehicle, you probably would not purchase any part.<n>L: If the price is 4% less than the total (that you would pay anyway)  then you would not purchase anything. If the missing vehicle cost $200 to repair ($100 each for the missing piece, for $1,000 total), then you should have purchased the missing

How many meals did he eat after his last activity?<n>Output: 5<n><n>Input:A man owns a car, a business, two horses, 3 dogs, and a bicycle. He has a home that he uses for both living and working. When working at his restaurant, he sleeps on a cot with an air condition. It does not take into account any particular student’s learning style, discipline, or learning preferences. Teachers are encouraged to consult an individual regarding individual student issues. We do not endorse any of the suggested answers. Each individual teacher is responsible for determining the scoring in his or her classroom and for recording the individual student scores at different times of the school year.

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. Your account is your account number.  When you ask for credits, we ask for your account number so that you can assign credits to yourself.<n>If you want to give $3 to a new player, you just give them an account number at $3.50 each and then ask for them to go create their account.   You can give credits to other players at different prices, but the more credits you give, the higher the price will be.<n>If you want someone to give $15 worth of credits to you, you just give him an account number at $15 and then ask him to go create their account with credits worth $5.00.<n>If you wish to assign credits to other players, you do the following:  You ask a player to go create a new account, then you assign him credits at the highest possible price.  You then ask the other players to give credits to you at that price.  The game starts.<n><n>NOTE:<n>The prices for credits are:<n>15 credits: $1<n>15 credits and less: $0.50<n><n>NOTE 2:<n>To assign a credit to another player, just tell the new player to go create their account, and then assign him credits at the price he asked for.  This is also referred to as "allowing."  Credit assignment is done only once.<n><n>You can give credits to other accounts at any price and any time, even after they have joined.  You can give credits when you ask a player to take

Eat.<n>Output: 5.14 cups of mayonnaise<n><n>(6)<n>[#]<n><n>Outline<n><n>Step One: Explain the example to the students.<n><n>Example 1: Find someone who is overweight and give them the above examples<n><n>Example 2: Cut up two slices of bread and sandwich a tomato (or pepper - which ever is most appealing to them) and a pepper (or whatever works for them) and a green pepper (or whatever works best for their taste as well as their stomach) and a sandwich 1 tomato (or pepper) and a green pepper. (which ever combination is most appealing to them). They should find the green pepper and tomato combo is best for their taste.<n><n>Use the same example and discuss the relationship between food and body weight.<n><n>Step Two: Give them the following question: "Who would you think that you would be most likely to eat before or during a dinner party?"<n><n>Step Three: Students then get 1 or 2 minutes to think about their answers.<n><n>Step Four: Assign students the task of guessing how many times the student wants to eat dinner before or during the evening with the above questions.<n><n>What do you get if you replace "they" with "they will eat dinner before, during, or after..."?<n><n>"They will eat...when they have had enough of the above example"<n>"They will eat in the afternoon...as they finish the example"<n>"They are happy with the above example and will eat the above in about 20 minutes because they are full"<n>"They will never eat anything from the above because it is too much to handle"

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day. One bag contains nuts and two bags contain dried fruits. Which bag do you pick?<n>Output: 3<n><n>Comments:<n>1) There are multiple versions of each of these sentences.<n>2) The most important question is not about price. If we know the price, then it can be asked to evaluate how much something cost.<n>3) The first question is a single choice question so it can be answered with a yes/no answer. This is important.<n>4) The second question is about quality. If they both were equally good it is impossible to answer. In fact, it can be a lie. When there is a price difference, it is important to compare the quality of the two products or items so we know for a fact how much something cost before they are purchased.<n><n>I am sorry this is so vague. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Output: 868<n><n>Input:James is apply for a job that he really wants. Choices:  A: acceptance B: rejection C: hope D: less sleep E: employment<n>Output:		 3<n><n>Input: What two things do you want to make sure you have before you graduate?  Choose one.<n>Output: 3 hours of sleep<n><n>Input: A man is arrested.  He is found incompetent to stand trial and is sent to a mental institution. If he is not released then the judge rules the man has not been insane, so he is not returning to the mental institution. What do you think his probability of return to the mental institute is?<n>Output:.02 or.001<n><n>Input: A woman has a child with the father.  The father is in jail.  The woman decides that she will keep the child.  Her friend gives her money she says that she owes him.  The woman pays up, takes the child to her home and tells her husband. Input:.09<n>Output:.02<n><n>Input: The amount of calories women must consume daily ranges from 2000 calories a day to 4500 calories a day. The result for this question has a range of 20-33 days, and it takes 33 days to achieve an average.<n>Input: 8,000<n>Output: 2,084 calories<n><n>Input: A child dies in the hospital after a six-hour coma, during which all symptoms had disappeared. Let the doctor give what the family physician says is the correct course of treatment.<n>Input: 10,000<n>Output: 3,091 calories

What % of the man's body is made up of his legs?<n>Output, 10 percent<n><n>Input (A):The formula is:<n>%bodyfat= bodymass**(1/3)<n>and %fat=100<n>Input (B):The formula is: *fat=*body mass**2<n>and %fat=% bodymass**1/100<n>Output (C):The formula is: **fat=**body mass**3<n>Output (D):The formula is: ***fat=****body mass****<n>Output (E):The formula is: ****=100<n>Input (F):The formula is: %bodysum= %fat<n>Input (G):The formula is: ##(100-50-9)=1##<n>Input (H):The formula is: f = ##f-2##<n>Input (I):The formula is: G = ##=x-x-y-z##<n>Input (J):The formula is: y = ##=x-y-z-x##<n>Input (K):The formula is: x = ##=x##<n>Input (L): The formula is: G = y=1x-*<n>Input (M): The formula is: h = ##h-y-z-y##<n>Output (N):The formula is: p = g = 1**x<n>Input (O):The formula is: h = p=1-*<n>Input (P):The formula is: g = g=1/100<n>Input (Q): The formula is: p = p = 1/3x<n>Input (R): The formula is: g = 1*<n>Input (S): The formula is: q = 1/3x+1/1/1/2<n>Input (T): The formula is: s = 1/4x+1/(1 + \*x)<n>Input (U): The formulas are: v = 1/

He can leave his container of flour in the cabin and then take his boat in the cabin. Or<n>4. A = (4, 3) + (2.5, 2). D = (1002, 10002) is also an answer but is not needed. You have to choose between a, b, c, or d. You should get d. You have to choose either the one with closest number of choices or the one with most appropriate answer<n>Output: A<n><n>Input: b is the result of the equation. c is the result of the same equation and it is the one you need. d is the result of the inverse function, it is the other answer, it does not help you and is not necessary. a is the answer so choose it<n>Output: A<n>### Answers:<n><n>Input: I don't have enough money to buy everything listed in this shopping list, so I decided to only buy the things and make do with less than the total. The total number of players is 1,000.  The total cost for tickets will be $75.  What is the probability of attendance by each of these players?<n>Output:  100<n><n>Output:<n>The number of goals scored in all of the games against Barca over the season by exactly two players in a campaign accounts for 20% of the total goals against Barca scored in the league that year.  If the players scored an even number of goals, this means they scored exactly one goal against Barca.  Note: if the players scored exactly 1 goal, the total number of goals will always be 2.  If the players are both scorers, their total number of goals also includes half a goal.  Note that the chance of one player scoring 30 against Barca each week is also 25%.<n>Output:  30<n><n>Input:The average number of goals scored per game for players in the top half of the goal distribution on average over a lifetime is 2.6.  Averaged over a year, that is the average goal-per-game amount is 4.9.  Given the number of players who scored 2.6 goals over their lifetime and 20 years of averaging the number goals players score over the life expectancy, that is the number of goals players are likely to score over the life expectancy of each one of them.  Since the number of goals players score over their life expectancy is 4.9, that is also the number of goals players who score exactly 2.6 over the last 20 years should score.  Note: if a player scored exactly 1 goal over their lifetime over the 20 years, that will also count as 1 goal and neither goal scored one week out of 20 and neither goal scored one year out of 20 will count as goals scored all over 20.  This is because those are just the week-to-week games players scored against Barca, and since the game against Barca is also a single-week game, the numbers are 1 week in all.<n>Output: 20<n><n>Input:How many goals does Ronaldo score per

But, in fact, I want to look at the role of the conductor in this. The conductor is the one who tells the passengers how long the train is supposed to take. The conductor is the person who tells the conductor to keep his/her train running on time. Here’s the question again. Which one of the two is actually the conductor? Which one is the person who tells everyone to keep their train running on time? That answer comes down to the way we’re used to calling them in Western countries. In English, the word conductor is usually used in context with a train conductor, i.e., the person who directs the conductors of the various train conductors. In English, that word is used for a particular “driver.” If we think

Please do not include any information from your question here in your response to the instructor.<n><n>1.If Tom is to start drinking water again from his first week after his drink of soda, he's likely going to find it difficult to drink, but over time will be acclimated to his new habit.<n><n>2. If Tom starts drinking an equal amount of water each day, compared to what he drank before for the first time, then the number of pounds gained during his initial diet will be relatively similar to the number gained before for any subsequent time period.<n><n>3. If Tom starts drinking water to replace his soda intake, he may begin to lose weight in response to this pattern -- particularly if he is very dedicated to staying on his plan and is exercising appropriately.<n><n>4. If Tom's initial diet included a moderate amount of protein and a moderate amount of carbohydrate, then weight loss will initially begin in response to a simple change of pattern -- the same reason that people who change their diet for other reasons may experience weight loss as well.<n><n>5. If Tom's initial calorie deficit for a given time period was the same for him each day, then weight loss will continue to follow a similar pattern over time as his body adjusts to a new diet.<n><n>6. If Tom was to increase his protein and dietary fat intake respectively, his weight loss would be very similar to the number of pounds gained upon eating a diet with these changes.<n><n>7. If TOM was to take a break for a week, his weight loss would likely be somewhat slower than if he does not change his diet.<n><n>### Question:<n>1. Tom has been eating a meal consisting of salad, cheese, and half a cup of meat and drink of soda or soft drink per day for 6 months.  What does he do differently now to accomplish his goal of eating one healthy meal?<n><n>2. How far away is Tom now from his goal of eating one completely healthy meal?<n><n>3. How far is Tom now from his new goal of eating one completely balanced meal?<n><n>4. How far is Tom from achieving his new goal of eating all vegetables five times a week?<n><n>5. How far away is TOM from achieving his new goal that he eat five different fruits and vegetables each day?<n><n>6. How far is TOM from achieving his goal of using natural muscle recovery stimulants each evening?<n><n>9-13

Choices:  A: football stadium B: apartment C: surface of earth D: car show E: house<n>Output:		 City<n><n>Input:The number of people that won the World Series in 1999 accounts for about 25% of all wins.  If everyone took 2 weeks holiday in 2000, and everyone lost their jobs, only 25% of all people would lose their jobs.  If everyone took 3 weeks, and everyone lost their job, then only 50% will lose their job. If everyone took 4 weeks, and everyone lost employment, then 66% will no longer lose their jobs.  The World Series' 1999 percentage of win total does not account for all that time off.  The figure should be adjusted to reflect only the two weeks of vacation in 2000. For example, if every man that won the World Series took 2 weeks holiday in 1999, and only took the standard 3 weeks in 2000, then the total for the season would be 0.  The same principle applies for 2000: for every 3 weeks holiday in 2000, each man will lose his job.<n>Output: 0<n><n>Input: The amount of money per month that you earn from selling your product is $100. Your answer also included the answer of the next question.<n><n>Answer each question to see your answers to the last question.<n><n>Example answers:Example 1:1) A banana costs $3 and a box of cereal costs $3.  Each of them has a weight of 60 grams. When Adam bought 3 kilograms of bananas and 3 kilograms of dried fruits, the entire cost came to $39.  Therefore, his total spend for the 3 kilograms of bananas was $12 ($12 + $5 - $10).2) A chicken wings has 4 pounds of meat and a pound of bird.  It would cost each of them $15 to buy the wings.  However, James had to get 4 gallons of chicken feed, and it costs $15 to feed him for a week.  Therefore, his spend on poultry is $40, and he would spend $16 for each of the 4 gallons chicken feed each week.3) James bought 5 boxes of doughnuts. Each box cost $1.50.  One box contains 8 doughnuts and one box contains 28 doughnuts. The cost is $3.00 ($3 + 3 + 1 + 28 = 4).  Accordingly, James would spend $9.00 each week on doughnuts.4) A horse weighs 1,000 pounds. You weigh him and use his weight to calculate the total you estimate he will pay for groceries if you decide to buy a package of the same size for that week.  What do you estimate the total cost will be if you buy a package of the above items?  Total Cost:$60<n><n>Example 2:<n><n>Input: An apple costs $1.49.  This does not include the costs of the packaging.  It does not include the fruit’s taxes, packaging fees, and taxes on a package of apples will be about the same as a package of donuts.  Therefore it costs $14.00 to buy apples.  What do you think you’ll spend on apples over the next week?<n>Output: $38.00<n><n>Input: If you want to buy a new toothbrush ($50), you have to start saving immediately. The percent is how often a single percentage point above an identical percentage point of yours is greater than, or equal to, a single one.  C: 10.25 E: 8.25<n>output: 35<n>Input: The maximum value for the percent is 25%.  The total dollar value when buying from the dollar store is $1.75 with the discount.  The value when going to an upscale grocer on opening night is $1.60 with the discount.  If you are going on a two-night night trip do the following math to calculate the value your dollar store has over an upscale grocery of the same size.  You can multiply the dollar sign by the percentage, in this case 10.50 to get a fraction that is 5 percent greater than $1.60 for the dollar store.  $5.14/dollar + $1.05/dollar = $4.20<n>output: 36<n><n>input: C. (2) C - 14<n>(3) A - 9<n>(4) B - 4<n>(5) E - 3<n>In (3) and  (4) what does D and D mean?  (6) A,C and E - the same<n>(7) D,E, F, & F - the same<n>You will do better when you use the correct pronoun.  Please select the pronoun(s) from the list below.<n>If you have trouble selecting one or more of the following, please use the help link under your answer:<n>(a) A - the parent<n>(b) B - the teacher<n>(c) C - the student's locker<n>(d) D - an object on the front porch<n>(e) F and F (or F & F, or F, F, F) - the parent and student<n>(9) D - the classroom<n>(3) F - the teacher's door<n>(7) B - the cafeteria or classroom<n>(8) D,E - the same<n>(9) D,E and F - the same<n>Choose the one that you're most familiar with and use in the next answer.  If you have trouble with the list, ask an instructor or TA. (This is especially true for some answer choices).<n>(a) A:  Teachers do not deliver the paper (b) B: A = class teacher's locker<n>(c) D:  Room teacher, not locker<n>(d) E:     teacher<n>(e) F:  The student's (g) locker<n>(g)   D = A or D<n>(h) f = the room (i) h = the school<n>(10) H:    the classroom's (12)    locker<n>(13) J:     the office's (15)    locker (17)       bag<n>(4) H - 17<n>You may substitute more than two pronouns. You should choose one and then use all others.<n>Click here to find out how to use the correct pronoun.<n><n>Click here for a full description of each question.

He puts one egg in the pan to fry. When you cook eggs, the yolks break off into thin air and rise to the top of the pan.  If no air gets inside the egg while the egg is in the pan, the yolks stay together. If the air inside the egg breaks off into thin air, they'll fall to the bottom of the pan.  John then has to put the yolk in a separate pan of boiling water, wait 5 minutes, then put the water on the other pan, where the yolks already have fallen, and wait another 5 minutes for the air trapped in the water outside the egg to reach its final resting place.  How long do they take?<n>Output: 3<n><n>Input:How often does Adam eat nuts and dried fruits?<n>Output: He eats nuts about 8 times a month.<n><n>Input:  The cost of the 1-kg bag of nuts was $50, then the cost of the 1-kilogram bag of dried fruits was $26, then the cost of 3 packs of dried fruit was $25, then the cost of 1 bag of nuts was $10 and the cost of the same bag of nuts were $5. A defensive end can block the line if the line of scrimmage is 20 yards to the left and a defensive tackle can block the line if it is 20 yards to the right; if the line is on the right, the position player who blocks the defensive linemen must be offensive. If the defenders all are defenders, the defensive end who can block the offensive line can also block the offensive line. A defensive tackle cannot block the offensive line either. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Output: 868<n><n>Input:Sam didn't like the people he met while traveling.  What might he do to get away from them? Choices:  A: come home B: airplane C: learn from each other D: go out E: make art<n>Output:		 3<n><n>Solution:<n><n>A: fly home<n><n>B: take a nap before or after a day of partying<n><n>C: learn from each other<n><n>D: go out<n><n>E: make art<n><n>Solution:<n>B: go out<n><n>C: learn<n><n>E: make<n><n>Solution:<n>A: learn<n><n>E : make art<n><n>Solution.<n>Solution.<n>Solution to a difficult math problem involves problems with large number of variables, like the one above.<n>A problem like the one above may be a difficult problem to solve, because the answer is uncertain.<n>Because the answer is uncertain, the value of any given variable may be large, causing all the answers to be false.<n>If you have a large number of variables, you should have a number of statements.<n>Statement 1 and Statement 2 are true.<n>Statement 3 and Statement 4 are false.<n>Statement 5 is true.<n><n>Statement 2 also says that there will be one more statement than Statement 1.<n>Therefore, statement 1 is correct.<n>Statement 2 is true.<n><n>There might not be that many statements that say 1.<n>You can add a statement that says it is 2.<n>To show how this can fit with Statement 3 is<n><n>Since statement 2 is true, Statement 3, Statement 4 and Statement 5 are true.<n><n>Solution.<n>First Statement has two parts.<n>For Statement 1, we know whether Statement 2 is true or false, and if Statement 1 is true or false, it is true.<n>Since Statement 2 is false, Statement 3, Statement 3, Statement 5, Statement 6 and Statement 7 are false.<n>Since Statement 4 is false, Statement 5 is true.<n>Since Position 9 is true, Statement 3 and Statements 5, 6 and 7 are false.<n><n>The answer does not have to be clear.<n>You should put a statement in there that says it is 3 and that it is 2.<n>You can make many statements that say 2, but you should keep the statements that say 3.<n>If you want to avoid that statement, or make the answer ambiguous, write<n><n>You probably did not understand the explanation of the first statement.<n>To make it easier to understand, you can include the following words:<n><n>Statement 1 tells you whether Statement 2 is true, false or false.<n>Statement 2 tells you that Statement 3 is true if Statement 1 is false and Statement 1 is true if Statement 2 is false.<n>Here
